trans-unit.source: Continuous delivery with Git and Visual Studio Online in Azure
trans-unit.target: Continuous delivery with Git and Visual Studio Online in Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to configure your Visual Studio Online team projects to use Git to automatically build and deploy to the Web App feature in Azure App Service or cloud services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to configure your Visual Studio Online team projects to use Git to automatically build and deploy to the Web App feature in Azure App Service or cloud services.

trans-unit.source: Continuous delivery to Azure using Visual Studio Online and Git
trans-unit.target: Continuous delivery to Azure using Visual Studio Online and Git

trans-unit.source: You can use Visual Studio Online team projects to host a Git repository for your source code, and automatically build and deploy to Azure web apps or cloud services whenever you push a commit to the repository.
trans-unit.target: You can use Visual Studio Online team projects to host a Git repository for your source code, and automatically build and deploy to Azure web apps or cloud services whenever you push a commit to the repository.

trans-unit.source: You'll need Visual Studio 2013 and the Azure SDK installed.
trans-unit.target: You'll need Visual Studio 2013 and the Azure SDK installed.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, download it by choosing the **Get started for free** link at [www.visualstudio.com](http://www.visualstudio.com).
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, download it by choosing the **Get started for free** link at [www.visualstudio.com](http://www.visualstudio.com).

trans-unit.source: Install the Azure SDK from [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=239540).
trans-unit.target: Install the Azure SDK from [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=239540).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You need an Visual Studio online account to complete this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You need an Visual Studio online account to complete this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: You can [open a Visual Studio Online account for free](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=512979).
trans-unit.target: You can [open a Visual Studio Online account for free](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=512979).

trans-unit.source: To set up a cloud service to automatically build and deploy to Azure by using Visual Studio Online, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: To set up a cloud service to automatically build and deploy to Azure by using Visual Studio Online, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a Git repository
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a Git repository

trans-unit.source: If you don’t already have a Visual Studio Online account, you can get one [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=397665).
trans-unit.target: If you don’t already have a Visual Studio Online account, you can get one [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=397665).

trans-unit.source: When you create your team project, choose Git as your source control system.
trans-unit.target: When you create your team project, choose Git as your source control system.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions to connect Visual Studio to your team project.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions to connect Visual Studio to your team project.

trans-unit.source: In **Team Explorer**, choose the **Clone this repository** link.
trans-unit.target: In **Team Explorer**, choose the **Clone this repository** link.

trans-unit.source: Specify the location of the local copy and then choose the **Clone** button.
trans-unit.target: Specify the location of the local copy and then choose the **Clone** button.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a project and commit it to the repository
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a project and commit it to the repository

trans-unit.source: In **Team Explorer**, in the **Solutions** section, choose the **New** link to create a new project in the local repository.
trans-unit.target: In **Team Explorer**, in the **Solutions** section, choose the **New** link to create a new project in the local repository.

trans-unit.source: You can deploy a web app or a cloud service (Azure Application) by following the steps in this walkthrough.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy a web app or a cloud service (Azure Application) by following the steps in this walkthrough.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Azure Cloud Service project,
trans-unit.target: Create a new Azure Cloud Service project,

trans-unit.source: or a new ASP.NET MVC project.
trans-unit.target: or a new ASP.NET MVC project.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the project targets the .NET Framework 4 or later.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the project targets the .NET Framework 4 or later.

trans-unit.source: If you are creating a cloud service project, add an ASP.NET MVC web role and a worker role.
trans-unit.target: If you are creating a cloud service project, add an ASP.NET MVC web role and a worker role.

trans-unit.source: If you want to create a web app, choose the **ASP.NET Web Application** project template, and then choose **MVC**.
trans-unit.target: If you want to create a web app, choose the **ASP.NET Web Application** project template, and then choose **MVC**.

trans-unit.source: See [Create an ASP.NET web app in Azure App Service](../web-sites-dotnet-get-started.md) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [Create an ASP.NET web app in Azure App Service](../web-sites-dotnet-get-started.md) for more information.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for the solution, and choose **Commit**.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for the solution, and choose **Commit**.

trans-unit.source: If this is the first time you've used Git in Visual Studio Online, you'll need to provide some information to identify yourself in Git.
trans-unit.target: If this is the first time you've used Git in Visual Studio Online, you'll need to provide some information to identify yourself in Git.

trans-unit.source: In the **Pending Changes** area of **Team Explorer**, enter your username and email address.
trans-unit.target: In the **Pending Changes** area of **Team Explorer**, enter your username and email address.

trans-unit.source: Enter a comment for the commit and then choose the **Commit** button.
trans-unit.target: Enter a comment for the commit and then choose the **Commit** button.

trans-unit.source: Note the options to include or exclude specific changes when you check in.
trans-unit.target: Note the options to include or exclude specific changes when you check in.

trans-unit.source: If the changes you want are excluded, choose **Include All**.
trans-unit.target: If the changes you want are excluded, choose **Include All**.

trans-unit.source: You've now committed the changes in your local copy of the repository.
trans-unit.target: You've now committed the changes in your local copy of the repository.

trans-unit.source: Next, sync those changes with the server by choosing the **Sync** link.
trans-unit.target: Next, sync those changes with the server by choosing the **Sync** link.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Connect the project to Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Connect the project to Azure

trans-unit.source: Now that you have a Git repository in Visual Studio Online with some source code in it, you are ready to connect your git repository to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have a Git repository in Visual Studio Online with some source code in it, you are ready to connect your git repository to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com), select your cloud service or web app, or create a new one by choosing the + icon at the bottom left and choosing **Cloud Service** or **Web App** and then **Quick Create**.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com), select your cloud service or web app, or create a new one by choosing the + icon at the bottom left and choosing **Cloud Service** or **Web App** and then **Quick Create**.

trans-unit.source: For cloud services, choose the **Set up publishing with Visual Studio Online** link.
trans-unit.target: For cloud services, choose the **Set up publishing with Visual Studio Online** link.

trans-unit.source: For web apps, choose the **Set up deployment from source control** link.
trans-unit.target: For web apps, choose the **Set up deployment from source control** link.

trans-unit.source: In the wizard, type the name of your Visual Studio Online account in the textbox and choose the **Authorize Now** link.
trans-unit.target: In the wizard, type the name of your Visual Studio Online account in the textbox and choose the **Authorize Now** link.

trans-unit.source: You might be asked to sign in.
trans-unit.target: You might be asked to sign in.

trans-unit.source: In the **Connection Request** pop-up dialog, choose **Accept** to authorize Azure to configure your team project in Visual Studio Online.
trans-unit.target: In the **Connection Request** pop-up dialog, choose **Accept** to authorize Azure to configure your team project in Visual Studio Online.

trans-unit.source: After authorization succeeds, you see a dropdown list that contains your Visual Studio Online team projects.
trans-unit.target: After authorization succeeds, you see a dropdown list that contains your Visual Studio Online team projects.

trans-unit.source: Select the name of team project that you created in the previous steps, and choose the wizard's checkmark button.
trans-unit.target: Select the name of team project that you created in the previous steps, and choose the wizard's checkmark button.

trans-unit.source: The next time you push a commit to your repository, Visual Studio Online will build and deploy your project to Azure.
trans-unit.target: The next time you push a commit to your repository, Visual Studio Online will build and deploy your project to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Trigger a rebuild and redeploy your project
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Trigger a rebuild and redeploy your project

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open up a file and change it.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open up a file and change it.

trans-unit.source: For example, change the file `_Layout.cshtml` under the Views\\Shared folder in an MVC web role.
trans-unit.target: For example, change the file `_Layout.cshtml` under the Views\\Shared folder in an MVC web role.

trans-unit.source: Edit the footer text for the site and save the file.
trans-unit.target: Edit the footer text for the site and save the file.

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, open the shortcut menu for the solution node, project node, or the file you changed, and then choose **Commit**.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, open the shortcut menu for the solution node, project node, or the file you changed, and then choose **Commit**.

trans-unit.source: Type in a comment and choose **Commit**.
trans-unit.target: Type in a comment and choose **Commit**.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Sync** link.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Sync** link.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Push** link to push your commit to the repository in Visual Studio Online.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Push** link to push your commit to the repository in Visual Studio Online.

trans-unit.source: (You can also use the **Sync** button to copy your commits to the repository.
trans-unit.target: (You can also use the **Sync** button to copy your commits to the repository.

trans-unit.source: The difference is that **Sync** also pulls the latest changes from the repository.)
trans-unit.target: The difference is that **Sync** also pulls the latest changes from the repository.)

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Home** button to return to the **Team Explorer** home page.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Home** button to return to the **Team Explorer** home page.

trans-unit.source: Choose **Builds** to view the builds in progress.
trans-unit.target: Choose **Builds** to view the builds in progress.

trans-unit.source: **Team Explorer** shows that a build has been triggered for your check-in.
trans-unit.target: **Team Explorer** shows that a build has been triggered for your check-in.

trans-unit.source: To view a detailed log as the build progresses, double-click the name of the build in progress.
trans-unit.target: To view a detailed log as the build progresses, double-click the name of the build in progress.

trans-unit.source: While the build is in-progress, take a look at the build definition that was created when you used the wizard to link to Azure.
trans-unit.target: While the build is in-progress, take a look at the build definition that was created when you used the wizard to link to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for the build definition and choose **Edit Build Definition**.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for the build definition and choose **Edit Build Definition**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Trigger** tab, you will see that the build definition is set to build on every check-in, by default.
trans-unit.target: In the **Trigger** tab, you will see that the build definition is set to build on every check-in, by default.

trans-unit.source: (For a cloud service, Visual Studio Online builds and deploys the master branch to the staging environment automatically.
trans-unit.target: (For a cloud service, Visual Studio Online builds and deploys the master branch to the staging environment automatically.

trans-unit.source: You still have to do a manual step to deploy to the live site.
trans-unit.target: You still have to do a manual step to deploy to the live site.

trans-unit.source: For a web app that doesn't have staging environment, it deploys the master branch directly to the live site.
trans-unit.target: For a web app that doesn't have staging environment, it deploys the master branch directly to the live site.

trans-unit.source: In the **Process** tab, you can see the deployment environment is set to the name of your cloud service or web app.
trans-unit.target: In the **Process** tab, you can see the deployment environment is set to the name of your cloud service or web app.

trans-unit.source: Specify values for the properties if you want different values than the defaults.
trans-unit.target: Specify values for the properties if you want different values than the defaults.

trans-unit.source: The properties for Azure publishing are in the **Deployment** section, and you might also need to set MSBuild parameters.
trans-unit.target: The properties for Azure publishing are in the **Deployment** section, and you might also need to set MSBuild parameters.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a cloud service project, to specify a service configuration other than "Cloud", set the MSbuild parameters to `/p:TargetProfile=[YourProfile]` where *[YourProfile]* matches a service configuration file with a name like ServiceConfiguration.*YourProfile*.cscfg.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a cloud service project, to specify a service configuration other than "Cloud", set the MSbuild parameters to `/p:TargetProfile=[YourProfile]` where *[YourProfile]* matches a service configuration file with a name like ServiceConfiguration.*YourProfile*.cscfg.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows the available properties in the **Deployment** section:
trans-unit.target: The following table shows the available properties in the **Deployment** section:

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Default Value
trans-unit.target: Default Value

trans-unit.source: Allow Untrusted Certificates
trans-unit.target: Allow Untrusted Certificates

trans-unit.source: If false, SSL certificates must be signed by a root authority.
trans-unit.target: If false, SSL certificates must be signed by a root authority.

trans-unit.source: Allow Upgrade
trans-unit.target: Allow Upgrade

trans-unit.source: Allows the deployment to update an existing deployment instead of creating a new one.
trans-unit.target: Allows the deployment to update an existing deployment instead of creating a new one.

trans-unit.source: Preserves the IP address.
trans-unit.target: Preserves the IP address.

trans-unit.source: Do Not Delete
trans-unit.target: Do Not Delete

trans-unit.source: If true, do not overwrite an existing unrelated deployment (upgrade is allowed).
trans-unit.target: If true, do not overwrite an existing unrelated deployment (upgrade is allowed).

trans-unit.source: Path to Deployment Settings
trans-unit.target: Path to Deployment Settings

trans-unit.source: The path to your .pubxml file for a web app, relative to the root folder of the repo.
trans-unit.target: The path to your .pubxml file for a web app, relative to the root folder of the repo.

trans-unit.source: Ignored for cloud services.
trans-unit.target: Ignored for cloud services.

trans-unit.source: Sharepoint Deployment Environment
trans-unit.target: Sharepoint Deployment Environment

trans-unit.source: The same as the service name.
trans-unit.target: The same as the service name.

trans-unit.source: Azure Deployment Environment
trans-unit.target: Azure Deployment Environment

trans-unit.source: The web app or cloud service name.
trans-unit.target: The web app or cloud service name.

trans-unit.source: By this time, your build should be completed successfully.
trans-unit.target: By this time, your build should be completed successfully.

trans-unit.source: If you double-click the build name, Visual Studio shows a **Build Summary**, including any test results from associated unit test projects.
trans-unit.target: If you double-click the build name, Visual Studio shows a **Build Summary**, including any test results from associated unit test projects.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com), you can view the associated deployment on the **Deployments** tab when the staging environment is selected.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com), you can view the associated deployment on the **Deployments** tab when the staging environment is selected.

trans-unit.source: Browse to your site's URL.
trans-unit.target: Browse to your site's URL.

trans-unit.source: For a web app, just choose the **Browse** button in the portal.
trans-unit.target: For a web app, just choose the **Browse** button in the portal.

trans-unit.source: For a cloud service, choose the URL in the **Quick Glance** section of the **Dashboard** page that shows the Staging environment.
trans-unit.target: For a cloud service, choose the URL in the **Quick Glance** section of the **Dashboard** page that shows the Staging environment.

trans-unit.source: Deployments from continuous integration for cloud services are published to the Staging environment by default.
trans-unit.target: Deployments from continuous integration for cloud services are published to the Staging environment by default.

trans-unit.source: You can change this by setting the **Alternate Cloud Service Environment** property to **Production**.
trans-unit.target: You can change this by setting the **Alternate Cloud Service Environment** property to **Production**.

trans-unit.source: Here's where the site URL is on the cloud service's dashboard page.
trans-unit.target: Here's where the site URL is on the cloud service's dashboard page.

trans-unit.source: A new browser tab will open to reveal your running site.
trans-unit.target: A new browser tab will open to reveal your running site.

trans-unit.source: If you make other changes to your project, you trigger more builds, and you will accumulate multiple deployments.
trans-unit.target: If you make other changes to your project, you trigger more builds, and you will accumulate multiple deployments.

trans-unit.source: The latest one is marked as Active.
trans-unit.target: The latest one is marked as Active.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Redeploy an earlier build
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Redeploy an earlier build

trans-unit.source: This step is optional.
trans-unit.target: This step is optional.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure management portal, choose an earlier deployment and choose **Redeploy** to rewind your site to an earlier check-in.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure management portal, choose an earlier deployment and choose **Redeploy** to rewind your site to an earlier check-in.

trans-unit.source: Note that this will trigger a new build in TFS and create a new entry in your deployment history.
trans-unit.target: Note that this will trigger a new build in TFS and create a new entry in your deployment history.

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Change the Production deployment
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Change the Production deployment

trans-unit.source: When you are ready, you can promote the Staging environment to the Production environment by choosing **Swap** in the Azure management portal.
trans-unit.target: When you are ready, you can promote the Staging environment to the Production environment by choosing **Swap** in the Azure management portal.

trans-unit.source: The newly deployed Staging environment is promoted to Production, and the previous Production environment, if any, becomes a Staging environment.
trans-unit.target: The newly deployed Staging environment is promoted to Production, and the previous Production environment, if any, becomes a Staging environment.

trans-unit.source: The Active deployment may be different for the Production and Staging environments, but the deployment history of recent builds is the same regardless of environment.
trans-unit.target: The Active deployment may be different for the Production and Staging environments, but the deployment history of recent builds is the same regardless of environment.

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Deploy from a working branch.
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Deploy from a working branch.

trans-unit.source: When you use Git, you usually make changes in a working branch and integrate into the master branch when your development reaches a finished state.
trans-unit.target: When you use Git, you usually make changes in a working branch and integrate into the master branch when your development reaches a finished state.

trans-unit.source: During the development phase of a project, you'll want to build and deploy the working branch to Azure.
trans-unit.target: During the development phase of a project, you'll want to build and deploy the working branch to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In **Team Explorer**, choose the **Home** button and then choose the **Branches** button.
trans-unit.target: In **Team Explorer**, choose the **Home** button and then choose the **Branches** button.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **New Branch** link.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **New Branch** link.

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of the branch, such as "working," and choose **Create Branch**.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of the branch, such as "working," and choose **Create Branch**.

trans-unit.source: This creates a new local branch.
trans-unit.target: This creates a new local branch.

trans-unit.source: Publish the branch.
trans-unit.target: Publish the branch.

trans-unit.source: Choose the branch name in **Unpublished branches**, and choose **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Choose the branch name in **Unpublished branches**, and choose **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: By default, only changes to the master branch trigger a continuous build.
trans-unit.target: By default, only changes to the master branch trigger a continuous build.

trans-unit.source: To set up continuous build for a working branch, choose the **Builds** page in **Team Explorer**, and choose **Edit Build Definition**.
trans-unit.target: To set up continuous build for a working branch, choose the **Builds** page in **Team Explorer**, and choose **Edit Build Definition**.

trans-unit.source: Open the **Source Settings** tab.
trans-unit.target: Open the **Source Settings** tab.

trans-unit.source: Under **Monitored branches for continuous integration and build**, choose **Click here to add a new row**.
trans-unit.target: Under **Monitored branches for continuous integration and build**, choose **Click here to add a new row**.

trans-unit.source: Specify the branch you created, such as refs/heads/working.
trans-unit.target: Specify the branch you created, such as refs/heads/working.

trans-unit.source: Make a change in the code, open the shortcut menu for the changed file, and then choose **Commit**.
trans-unit.target: Make a change in the code, open the shortcut menu for the changed file, and then choose **Commit**.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Unsynced Commits** link, and choose the **Sync** button or the **Push** link to copy the changes to the copy of the working branch in Visual Studio Online.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Unsynced Commits** link, and choose the **Sync** button or the **Push** link to copy the changes to the copy of the working branch in Visual Studio Online.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the **Builds** view and find the build that just got triggered for the working branch.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the **Builds** view and find the build that just got triggered for the working branch.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: To learn more tips on using Git with Visual Studio Online, see [Develop and share your code in Git using Visual Studio](http://www.visualstudio.com/get-started/share-your-code-in-git-vs.aspx) and for information about using a Git repository that's not managed by Visual Studio Online to publish to Azure, see [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](../web-sites-publish-source-control.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn more tips on using Git with Visual Studio Online, see [Develop and share your code in Git using Visual Studio](http://www.visualstudio.com/get-started/share-your-code-in-git-vs.aspx) and for information about using a Git repository that's not managed by Visual Studio Online to publish to Azure, see [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](../web-sites-publish-source-control.md).

trans-unit.source: For more information on Visual Studio Online, see [Visual Studio Online](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=253861).
trans-unit.target: For more information on Visual Studio Online, see [Visual Studio Online](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=253861).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
